body: Evan! Enrico Vezza shouted over his bullhorn, consulting the next name on his yellow legal pad, with the skill of a traffic policeman, he directed the youngman to a just-vacated barber chair toward the rear of the shop. Rico? Where are you, Rico? You're next! Mr. Vezza checked his list and surveyed the scene from the stool on which he towered over
title: New Haircuts, Vintage Shop

body: Now, H.S. for Writing Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado's collection of new and reorganized high schools will include a High School for Writing next fall. It will probably be housed in the building that until next year will be home to the School of Performing Arts, at 120 West 46th Street. The Chancellor has also talked about beginning a high
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Beginning next September, Midwood High School in Brooklyn - a public school - will offer special programs for selected students in cooperation with Brooklyn College, the city's Schools Chancellor has announced. Preliminary discussions are also under way between the Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, and Queens College to open a new public high school
title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS PLAN PROGRAMS WITH 2 COLLEGES

body: Argentina's military rule ended with the inauguration of Raul Ricardo Alfonsin as President amid joyous celebrations. Thousands of people gathered in the streets of Buenos Aires to cheer the President, a political moderate and leader of the Radi? cal Party, whose election has given?the country hope for a new beginning. (Page 1, Column 6.) The
title: NEWS SUMMARY; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1983; International

body: When Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn went to Congress three years ago, they arrived with similar ideas about solving the national housing shortage for low- and middle-income families. Faced with an Administration that favored less spending rather than more - and mindful of the paper work of previous
title: HOW 2 CONGRESSMEN FORGED LOWER-INCOME HOUSING PLAN

body: St. Francis Prep continued the Catholic League's domination of the Metro Bowl and completed an undefeated football season with a 42-6 victory yesterday over John Adams High School in the fifth annual game at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. Marlon Morris scored three touchdowns, Frank Rizzo scored two and Michael Rivera ran 50 yards with an Adams onside
title: ST. FRANCIS TROUNCES ADAMS IN BOWL, 42-6

body: When Angela Jones was born in the 1950's, the vast majority of black children were raised, as she was, in two-parent families. She is 31 years old now and divorced, the mother of a 3-year-old girl she is rearing in the Bronx under two difficult conditions: without a father and in poverty. Mrs. Jones, whose sweet expression hints of a gentler
title: A FAMILY: STORIES OF 7 BLACK WOMEN

body: Moments after John Adams defeated DeWitt Clinton last week to earn a second consecutive appearance in the Public Schools Athletic League championship game, Chris Ritter, the split end who played a key role in Adams's 6-0 victory, said that he did not have a preference for an opponent in the title game. ''If it's Midwood, it'll be a grudge match
title: QUEENS RIVALS TO PLAY FOR CITY SCHOOLS TITLE

body: Deon Frazier scored on an 8-yard pass with eight minutes left yesterday to give undefeated John Adams a 6-0 victory over DeWitt Clinton and a second consecutive trip to next week's Public Schools Athletic League championship game. The Spartans defeated Susan Wagner, 24-8, in the title game last year. They won the Queens A Division championship with
title: ADAMS AND BAYSIDE IN FINAL

body: Kathryn Ann Sklar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sklar of Hollis Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Mark Samson Ordan, son of Doris K. Ordan of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Harry Ordan. body: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. Indiana has not beaten the Nets in two years, a streak covering seven games. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 8:30 P.M.) title: SATURDAY SPORTS

body: There was so little time, none could be wasted on worrying, or even huddling. body: IN the 1630's, the Dutch farmers who settled in Brooklyn at what is now the corner of Flatbush and Flatlands Avenues looked around them, saw marshes, a bay and very little high ground and appropriately dubbed the area Flatlands. Not until the post-World War II building boom did Flatlands become a heavily populated residential area, but when it did,
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FLATLANDS

body: His football team has generally done poorly ever since losing to Bayside in the city championship game of 1981, but Coach George Najjar of Lincoln High School in Brooklyn has tried to make sure that each game, whether a victory or a loss, is an educational experience for his players. title: Lincoln's Season Is On Again

body: The director of pupil personnel services for the New York City public school system yesterday ordered a second Brooklyn high school football team to forfeit its victories this season because of an ineligible player, and then went a step further and eliminated the school from playoff competition. title: CANARSIE MUST FORFEIT GAMES

body: Lafayette Loses Plea on Forfeits Officials of the Public Schools Athletic League have upheld a decision requiring Lafayette High School's football team, an undefeated power in the Brooklyn A division, to forfeit six games in which it used an ineligible player. The forfeits left Midwood High School in first place with a 4-1 division record after a
title: No Headline

body: Lafayette Fate Undecided The championship of the Brooklyn A division will be determined in an office, not on a football field. Lafayette defeated Midwood yesterday, 24-7, in what was supposed to be a battle for first place. But there is a debate regarding the eligibility of a tailback who had played in all of Lafayette's previous games and the
title: No Headline

body: The principal of George Washington High School in Manhattan, citing injuries that his school's football team suffered in a game last weekend, yesterday canceled a game against DeWitt Clinton that was to have ended the regular season for both schools today. Waldemar Rojas, the principal, made the decision after meeting with Marlene Lazar, the
title: School Game Off Because of Injuries

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football

body: Madison High School extended its winning streak to six games yesterday with 20-14 victory over Sheepshead Bay, and moved a game closer to clinching a second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn B-division title. The Knights found themselves trailing going into the final quarter for the first time this season. But for Coach Steve
title: MADISON WINS 6TH STRAIGHT

body: IT has long been the conventional wisdom that families with children who cannot afford housing in Manhattan's choice neighborhoods have no alternative but to move to the the suburbs. title: 11 ALTERNATIVES TO COSTLY MANHATTAN

body: The semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's annual competition represent one-half of 1 percent of all high school seniors in the country. Next spring, 90 percent of the semifinalists will be selected as finalists on the basis of recommendations from principals, school records, scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test and short
title: A LISTING OF NATIONAL MERIT SEMIFINALISTS IN THE NEW YORK AREA

body: Coach Joe Prezioso kept his Clinton players low all week so that they'd be eager to fly when they played Kennedy. His strategy worked, as Clinton soared to a 16-0 victory yesterday. ''Usually we're high and loud all week, screaming and throwing high- fives,'' said Prezioso, whose team is 1-1 in league play after losing to Lehman, 13-8, in last
title: CLINTON BLANKS KENNEDY

body: One high school student was killed yesterday and one was injured when six students on their way home from Brooklyn Technical High School became involved in a fight with ten other youths, the police said. A police spokesman, Officer Fred Elwick, said the fight started at 3:05 P.M. when an argument between the two groups flared into violence at
title: THE CITY; Student Is Killed In Brooklyn Brawl

body: Some say there is a 1956 Chevrolet in the basement of the empty house on Avenue M in Brooklyn. Or a terrarium. Or neither of the above. Rumors have grown with the house - slowly. For about 20 years, neighbors have been watching and wondering as the house in the Midwood section remained unfinished and uninhabited. In the time it has taken to finish
title: 20-YEAR SAGA OF LITTLE HOUSE THAT COULDN'T

body: DRAWING CARD The court of Henry VIII, by virtue of history and legend, is one of the most glamorous of English reigns and, although we often see it reinterpreted in terms of theater and film, we rarely get to see its cast as it actually was in real life. This task fell to the happy lot of the artist Hans Holbein the Younger, who in the early 1500's
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Michael Bonnes, 19 years old, of 1364 East Fourth Street in Brooklyn, was arrested Tuesday night in the firebombing on Monday of a yeshiva, Chaim Berlin, in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. ... A 15-year-old Queens boy was charged yesterday with attempted murder in the shooting of Ray Tamayo, 14, in the playground of Junior High School 217 in
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: A 55-year-old Brooklyn woman was found shot to death in an apparent robbery in her apartment in the Midwood section yesterday afternoon, the police reported. Her hands had been tied behind her back and she had been gagged. Detectives of the 61st Precinct said the victim, whose name was withheld pending notification of kin and who lived alone at
title: THE CITY; Woman, 55, Slain

body: Sidney Weintraub, a professor of economics at the University of Pennsylvania who proposed using the Federal income tax to discourage wage and price inflation, died at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania of a heart-related disease Sunday. He was 69 years old and a resident of Philadelphia. Professor Weintraub taught for many years at the
title: SIDNEY WEINTRAUB DIES AT 69; AN ECONOMIST AND PROFESSOR

body: With 90-degree temperatures signaling the onset of outdoor activity for thousands of New Yorkers, two of the city's most visible problems -festering piles of curb-side garbage and large numbers of illegal street peddlers - are back again like the shimmering heat waves of summer. What happened to the city's recent crackdown on peddlers? Why do the
title: TWO PLAGUES THAT WILL NOT GO AWAY

body: In front of a house on Lafayette Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant stands a magnolia tree as big as a brownstone, its broad leaves as glossy as if each had been individually oiled. It is a magnolia grandiflora, and it usually grows nowhere north of the Mason-Dixon line. Somehow, improbably, with considerable help from human beings, this tree grows in
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; CITY OR BOROUGH, DODGERS OR NO DODGERS, BROOKLYN IS BROOKLYN

body: At Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I., yesterday Mary-Jane Moskowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Moskowitz of Port Washington, L.I., was married to Henry M. Dachowitz, son of Rabbi Pincus Dachowitz of Brooklyn and the late Seyma Sacksner Dachowitz. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from
title: Mary-Jane Moskowitz Is Married to a C.P.A.

body: BIG BRIDGE Does there exist in North America the artist, writer or poet who has not paid homage to the Brooklyn Bridge, the great suspension span that was the wonder of its age when it opened 100 years ago? It is difficult to think of holdouts as one sees the names summoned up to fashion celebratory exhibitions this year. Now that the bridge is up,
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Another professional football league was born yesterday, with several new twists. It plans to play from July to October, starting this year. It says it will be strictly a minor league, and as if to emphasize that, the players will not be paid. The six-team Atlantic Football League has planned its season to follow that of the United States Football
title: SCOUTING; Fans, Get Ready: Another League

body: The room is at Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, behind the sculpture of Atlas, up the escalator and to the left. It is the New York Passport Agency office, and if you want to avoid the crowd, arrive early. title: LONGISH WAIT AT STEP; 1 FOR TRAVELERS PURSUING PASSPORTS

body: ''T here's a really nice graveyard on East Third Street'' in Brooklyn's Midwood section, said 20-year-old Richard Colman. When he was at Edward R. Murrow High School, he ''used to go with friends to talk'' in the graveyard, which is part of Washington Cemetery. Now Mr. Colman, with his one-act play ''Third Street'' - which features the graveyard -
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Young Playwrights

body: Twenty years ago, Sabel's Kosher Bakery, halfway between 45th and 46th Streets on Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn, was the only store on the block to close for the Jewish Sabbath. Now, Osher Sabel, the Hasidic proprietor of the bakery, boasts that, with the arrival of other Orthodox merchants, they all do. It is one sign of a burst of Orthodox
title: ORTHODOX JUDAISM IS BUOYED BY A RESURGENCE IN NEW YORK

body: Politicians have become more involved this year in New York City's district school board campaigns than in any of the previous five elections since 1970, according to politicians and educators. The nine-member boards preside over budgets ranging from $15.5 million to $48.5 million a year. They also control the appointments of district and school
title: ELECTING BOARDS FOR CITY SCHOOLS HAS POLITICAL AIR

body: Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Moskowitz of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary-Jane Moskowitz, to Henry M. Dachowitz, son of Rabbi Pincus Dachowitz of Brooklyn and the late Seyma Sacksner Dachowitz. A May wedding is planned. Miss Moskowitz, until recently an administrative assistant at the Empire Steel Trading
title: Mary-Jane Moskowitz Plans Wedding in May

body: The demise of a 600-unit apartment complex in Brooklyn has pitted the 30 remaining tenants against the surrounding community as well as the landlord in a dispute over the landlord's efforts to empty the buildings. The residents of the complex - Midwood Gardens, an aging cluster of 11 apartment buildings in the Borough Park section - have accused
title: NEIGHBORS FAVOR A LANDLORD INSPUTE IN BOROUGH PARK

body: WITH Metropolitan Opera tickets going for as much as $60 each and Broadway not far behind, the service performed by New York's small opera companies becomes more precious with each passing year. The variety of material offered is wide, and, this being New York, the singers you hear on a small stage tonight may be the headliners at the Met tomorrow.
title: TOMORROW'S OPERA STARS MAY BE SINGING TONIGHT

body: kept gabled houses with o ak wainscoting, wide porch swings and deep window seats stand just a round corners from boarded-up storefronts. The community is many things to many people. title: IN YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN FLATBUSH

body: 'Rabbit Town' Honors a Friend M urray Lehrer remembers pink or blue ribbons on lobby mailboxes in Stuyvesant Town. It was the post-World War II baby boom, when young couples flocked to the new 8,732-apartment complex in the former Gashouse District, just above 14th Street from First Avenue to the East River Drive. Mr. Lehrer is the last of its 13
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: When a vacancy opened at one of the 110 New York City high schools under his jurisdiction, Frank J. Macchiarola made an unusual appointment: He took the job himself. What better way to understand the workings of a school, he explained, when he became acting principal of Jamaica High School in Queens. After nearly five years as New York City Schools
title: THE MACCHIAROLA YEARS: EDUCATIONAL PROGRESS MARKED BY POLITICAL CONFLICTS

body: ''There's no doubt about who's in charge - he's the captain,'' a correction union leader said yesterday of Thomas Aloysius Coughlin 3d, the New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services. The union leader, John Burke, who was present at the Ossining Correctional Facility during the long hours of negotiations to obtain the release of 17 prison
title: MAN IN THE NEWS; CHIEF OF STATE'S PRISONS: THOMAS ALOYSIUS COUGHLIN 3d

body: More than a third of the students in New York City high schools are chronically absent and miss so much class time that it is nearly impossible to teach them, according to the Board of Education. An additional 13 percent of the students are absent often enough to require extraordinary efforts by teachers to keep them up to grade level. Chronically
title: THIRD OF CITY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ATTEND CLASS TOO SELDOM TO LEARN

body: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1982. The center column shows the proportion of pupils in each school reading at or above grade level; the right-hand column gives each school's overall city-wide ranking.
title: Scores on Reading Tests Given in Public Schools

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 22 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. The department also named eight restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for failing to do so. The establishments are these: VIOLATIONS Henry's Deli & Restaurant, 195 E.
title: 22 Food Outlets Listed For Health Violations
